net.wstech2.me.httpsclient

Class CertificateValidator

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.wstech2.me.httpsclient.CertificateValidator
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    org.bouncycastle.crypto.tls.TlsAuthentication

    public class CertificateValidator
extends java.lang.Object
implements org.bouncycastle.crypto.tls.TlsAuthentication
    Validates a certificate chain against a external keystore (either the record store or a file embed in the jar). If HttpsConnectionImpl.isAllowUntrustedCertificates() is true then this certificate validator will ignore almost all mismatching attributes (validity, common name, signer , etc.). The only "always fatal" error is an invalid certificate signature when validated against the issuer public key, meaning that the server certificate was modified in transit. However, it is important to mention that if HttpsConnectionImpl.isAllowUntrustedCertificates() is true and no issuer certificate was provided, than the validation will still return "ok". The above mentioned "fatal exception" will occur only if the issuer/signer certificate is provided and the server certificate's signature can not validated using it.

      • validateCertificate

        protected boolean validateCertificate(org.bouncycastle.asn1.x509.Certificate cert,
                          org.bouncycastle.asn1.x509.Certificate issuerCert,
                          java.util.List errors)
                               throws org.bouncycastle.operator.OperatorCreationException,
                                      org.bouncycastle.cert.CertException,
                                      CertificateValidationException
        Validates whether the certificate is valid and if it was signed by the corresponding issuer Certificate/Key.
        Parameters:
        cert - the certificate to be validated.
        issuerCert - the issuer (normally a C.A.) certificate corresponding to the key used to sign the certificate indicated at the previous parameter.
        errors - a list to be filled - if needed - with errors detected during the validation process. See CertificateValidationException.setErrors(List).
        Returns:
        True if the certificate signature, start and end dates are valid. False otherwise.
        Throws:
        org.bouncycastle.cert.CertException
        org.bouncycastle.operator.OperatorCreationException
        CertificateValidationException

                           throws org.bouncycastle.operator.OperatorCreationException,
                                  org.bouncycastle.cert.CertException
        Validates the certificate signature (hash).
        Parameters:
        cert - The certificate to be validated.
        issuerCert - the issuer (normally a C.A.) certificate corresponding to the key used to sign the certificate indicated at the previous parameter.
        errors - a list to be filled - if needed - with errors detected during the validation process. See CertificateValidationException.setErrors(List).
        Returns:
        True if the certificate signature is valid. False otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException
        org.bouncycastle.crypto.InvalidCipherTextException
        org.bouncycastle.cert.CertException
        org.bouncycastle.operator.OperatorCreationException

      • verifyStartDate

        protected boolean verifyStartDate(org.bouncycastle.asn1.x509.Certificate cert,
                      java.util.List errors)
        Validates if the certificate's "start date" is valid. By valid we mean that it is <= current date.
        Parameters:
        cert - The certificate to be validated.
        errors - a list to be filled - if needed - with errors detected during the validation process. See CertificateValidationException.setErrors(List).
        Returns:
        true if the certificate's "start date" is less than or equal to the current date. False otherwise.

      • verifyEndDate

        protected boolean verifyEndDate(org.bouncycastle.asn1.x509.Certificate cert,
                    java.util.List errors)
        Validates if the certificate's "end date" is valid. By valid we mean that it is greater than or equal to the current date.
        Parameters:
        cert - The certificate to be validated.
        errors - a list to be filled - if needed - with errors detected during the validation process. See CertificateValidationException.setErrors(List).
        Returns:
        true if the certificate's "end date" is greater than or equal to the current date. False otherwise.
